content.content: Tooling & Utilities nominations for RetroPGF2 This is the thread to nominate projects for the Tooling and Utilities category of RetroPGF round 2. Please familiarize yourself with the Nominations process for RetroPGF round 2.   Overview of Timelines  Project nominations: Jan 17 19:00 GMT - Jan 31 19:00 GMT Final project opt-in deadline: Feb 21 Voting: Mar 7 - Mar 21   image1920×960 32.1 KB    Scope of this round RetroPGF round 2 is dedicated to projects that support development and usage of the OP Stack. For the category of Tooling + Utilities you may nominate  Work that helps builders create applications on Optimism mainnet Work that helps builders build on the OP Stack Work that helps builders interact with governance of the Collective Work that helps builders use applications built on Optimism  Note: The OP Stack refers to the OSS code powering Optimism. Today, this means the Optimism monorepo and its dependencies. Eligible projects need not be exclusive to the Optimism ecosystem, but there should be a connection. For example,   go-ethereum is an important dependency of the OP Stack, but is not Optimism-specific.  Ethereum L2 explorer pages which give stats on various L2s provide educational impact for the OP Stack, but are not Optimism-specific    How to Nominate a Project Things to consider when nominating a project:  Try to describe as best as you can how this project has delivered impact relating to the scope of this round. Make sure to nominate projects in the relevant category Before nominating a project please see if this project has been nominated already, so we can avoid duplication.  For Projects:  If you are a project looking to participate in this round please have a read of the Project Manual, it has an overview of the process and an FAQ section to answer questions that might come up. For your project to be eligible you will need to opt into the round and complete a project profile in the RetroPGF application manager by Feb 21 - 19:00 GMT. This will include providing more information about your project and verifying your Github or Twitter account. The application manager will be launched by end of Jan, more details to follow on this soon! Any project without a correctly verified GitHub or Twitter account, any project impersonating another team, any project not relating to the scope of the round, or any project without a complete profile may be hidden from the voting round at the Foundation’s discretion. Projects are allowed to nominate themselves. Here the term “project” can describe work that has been done by both an individual or a group. Collections, a term used to describe projects without a single person or entity that can be verified via GitHub or Twitter, may only be nominated by the Optimism Foundation.   Please use this template to Nominate a project:   The projects name:  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:  A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter:  (optional) contact info for the project or project lead:  Project Nominations will close by Jan 31 at 19:00 GMT

I think this belongs to this category?   The projects name: delegation.tools   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: When the OP token was launched there was some confusion on how users could change delegate after completing all the steps in the airdrop process. I created delegation.tools as a tool to let people see who they are delegating to and change delegate in a couple of clicks. Today it is still used. I started collecting anonymous statistics in October, they are public and you can see them here. Recently I started tracking how many times it was used to actually change delegate. In the last 30 days it has received ~4500 visitors which resulted in ~2000 changes of delegate.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: https://github.com/DanieleSalatti/op-delegation   Contact info for the project or project lead: Myself - you can message me here or on Twitter @DanieleSalatti

The projects name: Attestation Station Interface   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:  This project provides a no-code solution for builders and community members to directly interact with the AttestationStation smart contract. The Optimism team will (or already has used) it to help with the distribution of Citizen House voting badges. Allows anyone to create and read attestations.    A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Github   Contact info for the project or project lead:  Myself - you can reach me on twitter or email: sbvegan@protonmail.com

The project’s name: Solady  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Solady is an incredible Solidity library aiming to provide gas optimized and secure Solidity utilities. It is widely used across Solidity projects, many of which are deployed on Optimism, and it has served as an educational resource for many upcoming smart contract developers. As of right now, it is being maintained primarily by Vectorized as well as several open-source contributors. A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: GitHub - Vectorized/solady: Optimized Solidity snippets.  (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: https://twitter.com/optimizoor

The projects name: Pika Protocol  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Pika has one of the most fortunate potentials in Perpetual Trades. They have experienced and caring devs hyperfocused on presenting an ever progressing product. They are gaining more and more users everyday and considering the importance of perps in near future of crypto markets, they sure can be host to many new Optimism Traders. I believe they need grants to develop some essential parts of the dApp to be fully prepared for the mass adoption of Optimism. A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Twitter

I work at OP Labs, but making this nomination in my personal capacity.   The projects name: DefiLlama   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:   DefiLlama is a crypto data aggregator with dashboards and APIs covering DeFi TVL, DEX Volume, CEX Liquidity, token prices, DeFi yields, and more. DefiLlama also has high-quality data curation, which makes it a reliable source for the community, analysts, and developers (i.e. avoiding double counted TVL, splitting out native vs incentivized yield). As an example, the TVL APIs are my main data source for DeFi flows & OP incentive performance tracking (link). The dashboards and APIs are offered as a free public good, and have become a core resource for the crypto community.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter:  Website: https://defillama.com/ | API: API Docs - DefiLlama  Github: DefiLlama · GitHub  Twitter: https://twitter.com/DefiLlama     (optional) contact info for the project or project lead:  0xngmi: https://twitter.com/0xngmi

The projects name: Synpress   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Synpress is an e2e testing framework based on Cypress.io and playwright.dev with support for metamask. It’s currently used by Optimism, Synthetix, Kwenta, EY Blockchain, Agora, and about 130 additional repos on Github   Supporting a project like this is super beneficial to Optimism, as it ensures that developers’ apps on Optimism are properly tested and that time is used wisely (as manual testing is beyond painful) Jakub and Synpress have worked 1:1 with devs across Optimism to support them in using Synpress, and he would like to continue developing the project, expand the scope and features of the tool, and be able to better support developers on Optimism with testing automation.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: https://twitter.com/Synpress_   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: https://twitter.com/DRPTBL (Jakub from Synthetix)  Gitcoin Link -   Synpress - web3-enabled e2e testing tool | Grants | Gitcoin

Name: Attestation Station Interface   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:   This project provides a no-code solution for builders and community members to directly interact with the smart contract.   The Optimism team will/has used to distribute the Citizen House voting badges.   Allows anyone to create and read attestations.   A link to the project’s GitHub : Github

The projects name: GiveStation A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: What is GiveStation ? A multi-chain Give-To-Earn grant protocol where contributors get rewarded for funding public goods, ideas and projects in web3. http://app.givestation.org There are creators who create new grants under Optimism blockchain, 98% of the OP tokens allocated will be distributed to those who choose to contribute to these projects and the remaining 2% will be used to incentivize weekly activities like competitions and tasks where the users who partake in it will get OP as rewards. We leveraged on L2 technology and as at the time of this writing, we are currently live on testnet and have deployed the Dapp on 5 blockchain protocols including Optimism, Arbitrum, Polygon,  Binance and Gnosis and we do have more to come as we move further in the development process. On testnet so far, we have recorded the following. · Total number of grants created: 1,500+ · Number of active contributions on all 5 blockchain networks: 10,100 · Total GivePOINTS Earned — 1, 065 . Total OP earned - 0 Optimism Testnet guide is here: https://medium.com/@givestation/givestation-testnet-guide-optimism-8d3aa4997a6d Back in October 2022, we partnered with Quix NFT marketplace to give OP rewards to those who purchased our official NFT called Givnaut. Read more here: Get 5000 OP tokens as rewards. 🔴5,000 OP Partner rewards have been enabled for the Givnaut NFT collection! 👨‍🚀 https://qx.app/collection/0x0244F5c52bdA3fD44fC5c2a6bF6c30A2aC1Bd019 💰Boost amount … - GiveStation - Medium A link to the project’s GitHub: GitHub - MrBloomguy/givestaion-team-dapp: Created 202207072327 Twitter: https://twitter.com/GiveStation Contact info for the project or project lead: Co-founder (myself) - you can reach me on Twitter @0xmikki or email: oxplaymedia@gmail.com

The project name: Dune Analytics   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:   Dune is a powerful tool for blockchain research, complete with all the tools you need to discover, explore, and visualize vast amounts of blockchain data.   Dune allows builders to create their own dashboard with different key metrics by using crypto data collected from different applications and also allows users to easily explore the activity and data of different applications in the Optimism ecosystem.     A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter:   GitHub: Dune · GitHub   Twitter: https://twitter.com/DuneAnalytics

The projects name: Infinitism (ERC-4337)   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:   The Infinitism Team developed ERC-4337, the Account Abstraction proposal that avoids consensus-layer protocol changes. Work includes: i. The Entrypoint Contract: a singleton contract to execute bundles of UserOperations (the description of a user’s transaction) ii. A reference Bundler implementation & specification test suites: node or (block builder) that bundles multiple UserOperations and create a transaction. iii: Proof of concept implementations: A base wallet, Safe and BLS Wallet Their work is not exclusive to Optimism Network, but is already used by teams building on Optimism like us at CANDIDE Wallet and others like Biconomy.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Infinitism · GitHub @Infinisitm8 . Twitter   (optional) contact info for the project: @yoavw @yoavw . Twitter

I work at OP Labs, but making this nomination in my personal capacity. The projects name: Flipside A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: The Flipside Crypto team has worked alongside the OP Labs team to make Optimism data more accessible and help bootstrap Optimism’s ecosystem-wide attestation/identity efforts. The data tables, SDK, API, and other core services are offered as free public goods - enabling the creation of a wide range of products and tools for Optimism. Specifically, the Flipside team’s efforts and investments to the OP Stack include:   Data & Analytics Suite  Core Optimism data tables (blocks, transactions, event logs, and traces)  All entirely backfilled - data tables updated every two hours Ingesting OP data every 15-20 minutes   curated models for all aspects of Velodrome activity, NFT sales on popular exchanges (Quix/Seaport), and SushiSwap dimensional models for helpful dimensions such as contract labels, fact tables for important activities such as token transfers, token delegations, and hourly token prices data was used to calculate retroactive delegate rewards & voting participation:  OP Collective Gov Proposal Participation - OP Labs   adding an ez_dex_swaps table to cover the top dexes on Optimism 1892 analysts have run 850,000+ queries on Optimism data  137,000 queries in the last month alone (December 2022)      Software  API, SDK (software development kit), and data shares for unparalleled access & use in data science / visualization tools - including The Optimist Score ShroomDK - ShroomDK by FlipsideCrypto, API key NFT mint pulling the most comprehensive data set in all of crypto Snowflake Datashare, allowing data scientists to use and query Optimism data directly from the Snowflake UI for free -    Governance and Attestation Apps   https://op-governance.vercel.app/ - OP Governance Dash, displaying key governance metrics delegations, unique voters, active delegates, and specific requests per OP Labs team  new features such as 'Dark Mode’ links directly to the OP forum + delegation UI      https://science.flipsidecrypto.xyz/optimist/ The Optimist Score, built by the Flipside data science team, aiding with Optimism’s epic goal of providing on-chain attestation  code is entirely open-sourced, linked here  9000+ attestors and users of the app results and data queryable via SDK in JavaScript, Python, and R   Optimist Score Queries & Data - Flipside Crypto - example in R      A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter:  GitHub: Flipside Crypto · GitHub  Twitter: https://twitter.com/flipsidecrypto   Contact info for the project or project lead: Fig Gowen:  fig@flipsidecrypto.com  @fig on the forum

The projects name: Foundry  Ethereum Development Toolkit which has been built from the ground up in the Rust Language making it extremely fast, as compared with the more popular tooling  Suite of 4 tools (no hard limit)    Forge - Testing Framework   Cast - Swiss Army knife for interacting with EVM chains   Anvil - Local Ethereum Node   Chisel -  Solidity Repl   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:   - Indirect support for development of optimism stack   Major Advantages over existing tools   Robust Testing - Powerful testing set of functions  Beginner Friendly - All tests are written directly in solidity preventing the need to have mastery of some other language to do serious development  Open Source - Very active development, new features and bug fixes happen all the time  Active Community - Participative and willing to answer most basic queries  Description of my usage    Primarily for testing & bug hunting   Learning about ethereum development in general  A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter:   GitHub    GitHub - foundry-rs/foundry: Foundry is a blazing fast, portable and modular... Foundry is a blazing fast, portable and modular toolkit for Ethereum application development written in Rust. - GitHub - foundry-rs/foundry: Foundry is a blazing fast, portable and modular toolkit ...      (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: https://twitter.com/gakonst

The projects name: Vyper language Vyper — Vyper documentation   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Vyper is a contract-oriented, pythonic programming language that targets the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM).   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: https://twitter.com/vyperlang   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: @big_tech_sux

The projects name: Messari  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:  Messari has built comprehensive open-source subgraphs at the network level (note: WIP) as well as for individual projects on Optimism (Aave, Curve, Velodrome, QiDAO, etc.). We’ve used these to build live data dashboards tracking fundamental metrics (TVL, revenue, trading volume, loans originated, etc.) at the aggregate protocol level as well as for individual pools. We’ve also created freely available governance reports to help get better analytics to the the DAO in order to make more informed governance decisions.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Messari · GitHub Twitter   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: Telegram: @jackpurdy Email: jack@messari.io

I am nominating my own project, Revoke.cash.   The project’s name: Revoke.cash  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:  Revoke.cash is a suite of web3 security tools. It offers a dashboard to manage token and NFT allowances on Optimism and 30+ other chains. It also provides a browser extension that warns users when they are about to perform potentially harmful actions, such as approvals or NFT listings. By providing these services, users of Optimism and other supported chains enjoy more security while transacting on-chain and interacting with other applications on Optimism. The project name: ethers.js   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:  ethersjs aims to be a complete and compact library for interacting with Ethereum, and is arguably one of the most widely used libraries in the space with nearly a million weekly downloads without this tooling, it would be significantly harder for developers to build the applications that will ultimately run on the OP Stack  ricmoo has been actively and diligently maintaining this infrastructure for years in good faith without any expectation of return    A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter:  GitHub: Ethersjs · GitHub  Twitter: https://twitter.com/ricmoo

The projects name: Remix IDE   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: The Remix IDE is a rich toolset which can be used for the entire journey of contract development on EVM compatible chains. Without this project, it would be significantly harder for developers to build applications on the OP Stack. I used it to deploy my first smartcontract on Optimism.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: GitHub - ethereum/remix-ide: Documentation for Remix IDE https://twitter.com/EthereumRemix

The projects name : Gitcoin   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Gitcoin is a platform where you get paid to work on open source software in Python, Rust, Ruby, JavaScript, Solidity, HTML, CSS, Design, and more. Gitcoin is going to help Optimism in allocating the fund in the retroPGF2 to different projects through voting on their platform   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Github: Gitcoin DAO · GitHub Twitter: https://twitter.com/gitcoin

The projects name: Pika Protocol   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Pika has promote Perpetual Trades on OP Ecosystem. The team is 100% focused on product & community. They are increasing users and TLV day by day. A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Twitter

The projects name: Rigoblock   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Rigoblock is a fully open source and free to use set of solidity smart contracts that facilitates the interaction with DeFi applications, live on Optimism since November 2022. Rigoblock liquidity has generated more than 50MM USD token swap volume on Ethereum mainnet. Our pools have been providing liquidity on Uniswap v3 on Optimism, including OP token pairs. Rigoblock’s GRG token has been airdropped to 9k wallets on Optimism. Work that helps builders create applications on Optimism mainnet:  enabling any holder to use a cold key for moving tokens from/to a Rigoblock smart wallet and a “hot” key (that can be stored on i.e. a mobile wallet) for moving the tokens within said smart wallet, i.e. swaps, providing liquidity; enabling the organisation of groups of token holders under “umbrella” smart pools operated by a pool operator. deterministic proxy factory which seamlessly generates lightweight proxies with same-address on each chain (where it gets deployed). original approach to smart contract storage which prevents accidental storage collision between proxy and implementation, improving smart contract security, usable by any developer in their own protocol/application under the Apache2.0 License.  Work that helps builders use applications built on Optimism:  minimizing the DeFi smart contract risk. Each time a wallet is required to set an allowance to an external application, the protocol approves the amount, executes the transaction and removes the allowance without clearing storage, avoiding unnecessary gas costs (i.e. approval abstraction); precompiling and batching multiple transactions. An Optimism user can send one transaction to its Rigoblock pool and execute multiple transactions on one (or many) external application simultaneously. This is also relevant for governance operations that require multiple transactions by a user, improving UX, which is particularly important for governance participation; a simple interface to interact with DeFi applications through Rigoblock.    A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: RigoBlock · GitHub   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: admin@rigoblock.com

The project’s name: RainbowKit Login (WordPress Plugin)  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: WordPress powers a huge chunk of the web. Unlocking integrations between WordPress and web3 represents a major opportunity for usage. RainbowKit Login supports Sign-In With Ethereum and token-gating/role mapping with the Optimism network. By providing the rails for integrating Optimism and WordPress, RainbowKit Login helps builders build and use applications on the OP Stack.  A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: GitHub - davisshaver/wp-rainbow: WordPress Plugin to Enable Sign-In With Ethereum using RainbowKit   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: Davis Shaver, davisshaver@gmail.com    Screenshot 2023-01-23 at 8.58.39 AM736×220 24.5 KB

Nominating our project:   The projects name: TogetherCrew (community health research project by RnDAO)   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: TogetherCrew has developed, for over ten months of work, a research-backed framework to meaningfully assess community health, identify opportunities for improvement, and evaluate the success of community initiatives. The framework can now be easily applied to assess and benchmark a community (e.g. Optimism) thanks to an open-source data collection tool for discord (other data sources are in the works).   See first research paper here: What is a DAO Community and when is it healthy: a working paper … — RnDAO   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: https://twitter.com/rndao__   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: https://twitter.com/_daniel_ospina

The projects name: DexKit   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:   We develop open source tools aimed at crypto entrepreneurs and the general public. Users of our platform are able to create Smart Contracts and web development solutions without a single line of code. Our focus is ease of use without sacrificing security or speed, including the specific documentation we have for each of our products. Users of Optimism can create an NFT marketplace with a token swap interface or NFT collection in seconds without any cost, even without paying network fees. Our solution has been live already for a couple of months here whitelabel-nft.dexkit.com/ and the Open Source code of this product can be found here DexKit Open Marketplace. It’s running successfully on 0x v4 smart contracts.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: DexKit · GitHub   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: info@dexkit.com

The projects name: Velodrome Finance A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Velodrome is the great product that helped onboard a lot of dApps to the Optimism ecossystem, one of them that I use much is Sonne Finance. Velodrome is one of the protocols that make me choose to use only Optimism network. A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: twitter.com/VelodromeFi Contact info for the project or project lead: Twitter: twitter.com/wagmiAlexander Discord: alexcutler.eth#0399 The projects name: Sonne Finance A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: They helped onboard a lot of users for their simplicity to lend and borrow assets. The UI/UX is great and they try to build trust on the ecossystem, so this is alling with Optimism’s view. The community is great and the team is always available on discord for feedbacks and to help users. A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: twitter.com/sonnefinance Contact info for the project or project lead: Twitter: twitter.com/DefiIntro Discord: atakan-IntroToDefi#7962

Hello all - excited to make some nominations. Disclaimer: I’m doing this in my personal capacity, not as a representative of Coinbase. The projects name: Rotki A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Rotki is an open source, privacy protecting portfolio tracking app. They recently added Optimism support. Their tooling will allow Optimism users to better manage their portfolio and taxes. This is invaluable to users of the Optimism ecosystem. A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: https://twitter.com/rotkiapp

The projects name: QuestBook   How the project has supported the development and usage of the OP Stack: By enabling protocols to give out grants to competent builders in a transparent manner, Questbook has accelerated the growth of the Web3 ecosystem as well as the OP Stack. Questbook is a decentralized grant management platform. The platform is open-sourced, transparent, and deployed on Optimism. All the grants on Questbook are given out on the OP Stack. That means, builders submitted their proposals, received reviews and community feedback, all via the Optimism Chain. By using the tool,   Grant managers have created, reviewed, accepted, tracked, and facilitated grants worth $2.1M   1500+ Builders have applied for various grants, reported milestones and funding, and received feedback.   The entire grant flow on the tool is transparent, on-chain and accessible to the community.  public proposal flow2880×1800 497 KB    Questbook has enabled protocols built on Optimism such as Aave, Perpetual, and Biconomy to give out grants to builders who will contribute to the OP Stack again. The tool is currently being used by 20k+ builders, and $2.1m worth of grants have been facilitated. Questbook has also relaunched Compound Grants Program 2.0 as a community-run grants program, to disburse $1M to the builders.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: https://github.com/questbook   Contact info for the project or project lead: @harsha.questbook   For more details, please go through this!

I’m nominating rotki, a local-first, fully open source portfolio manager licensed under AGPL (meaning it’s free software, a public good). Project name: rotki - open source portfolio tracker, accounting and analytics tool A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: rotki used a Phase 1 grant to integrate Optimism into the app. The development has been completed and is ready for use on the develop branch, which will be released soon. As rotki is free and open source, anyone is free to build on top of it, or to re-use the code in their own software. This makes it an obvious fit for the first two areas of the scope of this category. On top of that, the founder and CEO of rotki, @lefterisjp is a well-known and active member and contributor to the Optimism Community, one of the top 10 delegates of the Token House. His views and actions are well aligned with the Optimism Collective’s mission, and he puts them into practice in rotki’s architecture and development. It’s important to note that even if someone is not an active Rotki user, it’s in their best interest to see Rotki used and developed, as it’s probably the only local portfolio tracker that puts user privacy and security ahead of fancy UX and catchy features. The fact that we have free, open source software integrated into our crypto infrastructure ensures that this infrastructure is still trustless and permissionless. Even if you don’t use a local portfolio manager right now, it’s important to be able to use it because it ensures that you can keep your data private and secure at all times, without relying on centralised services or intermediaries. A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Github: Rotki · GitHub Twitter: https://twitter.com/rotkiapp Discord: Rotki Website: https://rotki.com/ (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: Lefteris Karapetsas https://twitter.com/LefterisJP @lefterisjp

The projects name: EthereansOS   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: EthereansOS launched two iterations of it’s DeFi suite (Covenants) and new NFT standard (ITEMS) on Optimism. The dev team is dedicated to using Optimism to facilitate future implementations of these tools to help developers onboard to Optimism and create the next generation of dapps using secure coding practices (with the Factories model) as well as complex governance structures using Organizations (DAO tool suite).   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: https://twitter.com/ethereanslabs   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: https://twitter.com/toschi_eth

The projects name: Snapshot A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Snapshot has been used both by the Optimism Collective and 64 projects on Optimism to facilitate governance. All of these services have been provided for free, both for governance participants and the projects themselves. This has allowed Optimism to be the most active layer 2 in terms of governance and establish a strong ideological stance of decentralization and participative decision-making in the entire ecosystem. Snapshot allows projects to conduct votes that most of the people reading this forum have participated in. Since the start of Optimism’s governance:   1.15M votes have been cast in the Optimism collective’s governance on 93 proposal.  88650 participants have voted, which means the average participant has voted 13 times on average, the highest number for any major DAO.  A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Snapshot Labs · GitHub & https://twitter.com/SnapshotLabs Contact info for the project or project lead: @nathan_vdh on Telegram, @SnapshotLabs on Twitter

Mean Finance is a protocol that enables dollar-cost-averaging to certain crytocurrencies. What is DCA? Dollar-cost averaging is the practice of systematically investing equal amounts of money at regular intervals, regardless of the price of the asset. https://mean.finance/  allows users to DCA ERC20 tokens on Arbitrum, Matic, Optimism. Automatically. https://twitter.com/mean_fi Recently, Mean launched a yield-bearing-DCA program. This means users can earn yield on a DCA position. I believe that this protocol, thanks to its solutions, will attract a large number of users.

Project: Dune Analytics   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:  Dune Analytics is a tool for blockchain research. It can be used to query, extract, and visualize blockchain data, is probably the strongest blockchain data analytics tool currently available to the public. With Dune you get near real-time access to blockchain data through a public database that you can query through Dune’s website using SQL.    A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter:  Twitter GitHub

Nom du Projet: Pika Protocol Descriptif: Le projet Pika Protocol est composé d’une équipe compétente qui est à l’écoute de sa communauté. Elle prend en compte les retours de sa communauté afin de rendre un produit optimal et adapté au plus grand nombre. La preuve en est que sa plateforme a vu ses chiffres (Utilisateurs notamment) grimper au fil des mois. Enfin, Pika Protocol a mis en avant les échanges perpétuelles sur OP comme a pu le mettre en avant un des mes camarades ci-dessus. Twitter: https://twitter.com/PikaProtocol

The project name - rust-cannon-template  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: The Rust Cannon template is a kicking off point for developers who want to build and experiment with the provable execution layer of the OP stack. It makes it simple to compile Rust code to MIPs with helpers to read inputs, write outputs and access the pre-image oracle. The results of the execution of this code can be fraud-proven on-chain using the OP stack Solidity contracts. Currently Optimism only maintains a Golang stack part of the official Cannon repo. This template came about as a side project from the 2022 EthBerlin hackathon. It has already been used in the DevCon hackathon (by a team I was part of) to build Zipline a Ethereum light-client bridge based on the OP stack which is seeing continued development. It is difficult to estimate how many developers have used the template so far but as of writing it has around 20 stars on Github. Lowering the barrier to entry for developers to experiment with this part of the stack is important to encourage hacking and innovation going forward. Project Name timdaub’s work as an Ethereum Magician developing Soulbound token standards, EIP-4973 and EIP-5192 Description: EIP-5912 and EIP-4973 are standard extensions for NFTs to lock tokens by blocking their transfer functionality. Developers can implement conditions to loan NFTs as collateral, build social recovery mechanisms (Soulbound tokens / non-transferable Tokens / NTTs) or use them as role markers (what we do at Otterspace). Tim Daubenschütz pioneered the work on non-transferable tokens (with EIP-4973). Upon release of the DeSoc paper, Tim worked with the community to address their concerns around privacy and consent. He organized workshops, gave talks, and interviewed users at multiple conferences in 2022. He expanded the non-transferable tokens narrative with various articles (links below) outlining his vision. At Otterspace we have built atop of Tim’s work and today, over 950 Otterspace Badges have been minted on Optimism using Tim’s standards. Additionally, various other projects (> 200 developer references in GitHub) are building non-financial use cases based on his work. While we at Otterspace funded Tim’s work (2 months) to implement EIP-4973, the majority of his work (> 1 year) remains unpaid. Tim is a big fan of Optimism’s RetroPGF. He successfully nominated the LeapDAO in R1 ( 1.6 ETH). Having faced the community’s critique on Soulbound tokens, developed a solution, and implemented a standard that stands to become the go-to-standard for non-transferable tokens, I believe, Tim would be stoked to receive funding for his work as it confirms its merit, improves his financial stability, and will allow him to double down on more standard development. In my opinion, an Ethereum Magician like Tim is the perfect candidate for RetroPGF! Links  Tim’s blog Tim’s profile on Ethereum Magicians Ethereum Magicians:  Tim’s ERC Lightning Talks session at Devcon Bogotá on Youtube  EIP-5912  Reference Implementation PEEPanEIP #89: EIP-5192: Minimal Soulbound NFTs with Tim Daubenschütz    EIP-4973  Reference Implementation     Blog posts:  What are Account-bound tokens? How EIP-4973 can help the music NFT industry! EIP-4973 allows for mutually agreed, peer-to-peer minting - without implicitly determined power distributions    Contact  About page on Tim’s blog  Disclaimers We (Otterspace) have funded Tim’s work for two months in May 2022 and July 2022.

The project’s name is Remix IDE. Remix IDE is a powerful and versatile integrated development environment (IDE) that is specifically designed to support the development and deployment of smart contracts on Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) compatible blockchain networks. It provides developers with a wide range of tools and features that make it easy to write, test, and deploy smart contracts, as well as interact with them once they are deployed. One of the key advantages of Remix IDE is its support for the OP Stack. The OP Stack is a set of open-source tools and protocols that enable developers to build and deploy decentralized applications (dapps) on the Ethereum blockchain. Without Remix IDE, developers would have to rely on a combination of command-line tools and text editors, which can be time-consuming and error-prone. With Remix IDE, developers can use a single, unified interface to write and test smart contracts, deploy them to the blockchain, and interact with them in real-time. This makes it much easier to build and maintain dapps on the OP Stack, and allows developers to focus on the logic of their contracts rather than the technical details of deployment. In conclusion, Remix IDE is an essential tool for any developer looking to build and deploy dapps on the OP Stack. It simplifies the development process and provides a range of powerful features that make it easy to write, test, and deploy smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter:  https://twitter.com/EthereumRemix

The projects name Scry Protocol   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack Scry has deployed the Open Oracle Framework, an infrastructure for oracles for developers to access external data in a fully permissionless and decentralized way. The infrastructure allows devs to deploy high scale oracles for any API with the contracts, nodes and front end all ready to use in <15m. This allows devs to create oracles using their own reputable signers in their communities or use a reference oracle by the Scry team to request data to be brought onchain. Optimism is severly underserved by other oracle networks with not even 50 feeds by the largest oracle providers, while Scry enables >200 feed updates with just 1 tx. These feeds also allow new capibilities such as onchain historical lookup for feed values at any timestamp, no code deployment and feed management and custom signer sets that can be updated. New feeds can be deployed in <60s to deployed oracles allowing high-scale data in realtime. Scry allows new use cases such as insurance, financial tools and non financial tools which need external data to be able to deploy to the Optimism network with very little resource requirements and time getting the data there. The factory allows easy oracle deployment by devs without even needing to deploy a contract using hardhat themselves, just a simple etherscan tx, a script and they’re operational. The documenation can be found at Introduction - Scry Protocol Custom Optimism Front End for all oracles to have a front end for data exploration https://optimism.dapp.scry.finance/ The infrastructure is fully decentralized and the ONLY protocol in the space that allows devs to deploy their own oracles and control the oracle and feeds fully using their own security/signers/feed sources, as well as wrapping this into a very simple process to allow for rapid deployment and usability. The deployments have no cost, the node/front end and contracts are all open source. The oracles simply take n signers with t threshold and the oracle returns the med val from n signers that submitted the feed, as long as t signers have submitted for a given slot, the slot being how often the oracle should update. Further grants funds will go towards a reference oracle to allow devs to just request feeds if they do not wish to deploy their own oracle and help serve devs on the fly for data they need, being used for gas to maintain the oracle updates.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: ScryProtocol · GitHub   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: PR0#9619 Discord pr0@keychain.me hey@scry.finance

The project’s name: dm3 - a protocol for interoperable web3 messaging. A description of how the project has supported the development and usage of the OP Stack: With the dm3 protocol, we provide a web3-based messaging protocol focused on end-2-end encryption, decentralisation, scalability, and interoperability. The main features of the dm3 protocol are:  to initiate a ‘central’ registry (utilising ENS) for the information necessary for secure communication, such as public keys for encryption and signatures, and delivery information, and to enable a decentralised and scalable network of independent self-sovereign delivery service nodes.  Currently, Optimism has counted several projects focused on social or messaging interactions: Alchemy, Atlantis World, Etherscan, Gnosis Safe, Nansen, Zerion and counting. With the Interoperability Initiative we are committed to enabling the secure exchange of messages between different protocols, services, and applications using the dm3 protocol to enable an interoperable web3 messaging ecosystem, but also to integrate communication registry information sources like other chains and services, and especially in the Optimism ecosystem. With freely usable components (dm3 embedded widgets, open-sourced under BSD license), dApps can easily integrate messaging functionality with minimal effort (e.g. in-dApp communication, support channels, etc). Optimism can now be ideally used to publish dm3 communication profiles so that users of dApps can communicate with users of any dm3-compatible application or service. The dm3 protocol as a Public Good welcomes any participant of the messaging and social ecosystem to integrate with the dm3 interoperability initiative, and by doing so, also integrates with the Optimism Ecosystem. In conclusion, we built an open standard for messaging and we are bringing it to Optimism. A link to the project’s GitHub, Twitter, and website: You can find our open source project at github (specification and reference implementation) and on twitter at @dm3protocol. The website with more information on the dm3 interoperability initiative and dm3 embedded components, incl. the working reference implementation can be accessed at www.dm3.network. Contact info for the project or project lead: Our technical lead is Steffen Kux (@stkux on Telegram, steffen@dm3.network via email) Thanks for reading about our protocol!

Project name Hardhat  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack Hardhat is the most popular Solidity development environment across all EVM networks and is used by the majority of Ethereum developers. Optimism has directly benefited in at least three different ways: 1. Direct use by the Optimism team to build Optimism itself, including contracts and testing infrastructure This is visible on Github. The Optimism team also built internal Hardhat utilities to interact with the protocol. 2. Hardhat plugins by the Optimism team for the community to be able to build and test early on Hardhat is designed as a platform for developer tooling to be built on top, which allowed the Optimism team to build different utilities and plugins that made it compatible with Optimism early on when the tech had more discrepancies with Ethereum than today. Hardhat was leveraged to bootstrap Optimism as it was initially the only dev tool available to build on Optimism. The team directly built two plugins for this purpose:   @eth-optimism/plugins/hardhat/compiler. Integrated Optimism’s custom compiler at the time. Now a legacy component.  @eth-optimism/plugins/hardhat/ethers. Integrated Optimism’s ethers.js fork. Now a legacy component.  In addition, they also built Smock on top of Hardhat for internal use, which is now community-driven and heavily used for mocking across the wider ecosystem. 3. Usage by the Optimism community to build smart contracts that run on Optimism Many developers use Hardhat to build the apps and contracts that they run on Optimism. The widely-used and officially maintained hardhat-etherscan plugin also supports Optimism directly. The projects name: Pairwise A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Pairwise is a novel voting pattern and dapp that makes it easy and fun for web3 communities to signal their preferences. If this project can be well funded, it will enable much greater engagement for web3 communities across the ecosystem. Pairwise aims to make it easier for Web3 communities to signal their preferences and make informed decisions. Pairwise is designed to be user-friendly and intuitive, like a dating app, allowing users to choose between pairs of options to signal their preferences as opposed to having to read endless forum posts and vote within a set time period. The system converts these simple subjective inputs into objective, measurable outputs, minimizing the cost and cognitive burden of voting. The goal of the project is to promote greater community engagement in DAO’s decision-making processes. But not only can Pairwise be used for governance with different snapshot strategies, but Pairwise can also be used to allocate budgets based on community signaling. And that’s just the beginning - we can’t wait to see how the community will discover and utilize all of the potential use cases for this tool. I’m part of Velodrome Finance team, and I’m the author of Sugar.  Sugar: makes Velodrome devs life sweeter Sugar was born as the need to unify the 10+ contracts handling Velodrome into an easy to use interface with full access to the normalized dataset representing the real-time state of our protocol. This massively reduced our RPC costs and improved our V2 UI/UX. It reduced the development time and maintenance, and allowed to onboard partners into protocol mechanics with minimal effort. On the smart-contract development side, it exposed ABI design issues and performance optimizations opportunities. On the infrastructure side, it exposed issues where Vyper support on optimism can be improved and issues with it on optimistic.etherscan.io which we reported back to the OP team. Sugar is also new, I haven’t seen anything like it done before and the reason I’d like to highlight it is mainly for educational purposes. Developers are free to use it to integrate Velodrome liquidity pool data and even historical emissions, veNFT status and available rewards or just display the voting distribution. I believe OP Stack could benefit a lot from good UI/UX and we should strive to achieve that without Web2 solutions  Github: GitHub - velodrome-finance/sugar: Sugar makes Velodrome devs life sweeter 🍭

Nominating Data Analysts who made notable contributions to making Optimism data easily accessible (#2)    The projects name: hildobby (Optimism Dashboards & NFT Wash Trading Logic)  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:  Among the many public utility dashboards Hildobby has made, they built the canonical Optimism DEX dashboard (some data is blank to due in-progress migrations to Dune v2), and a dashboard covering OP Airdrop #1. They’ve also been the industry leader in NFT Wash Trading research, after incentive programs from upstart marketplaces led to inorganic volumes. This work was eventually documented, made easily accessible via a Dune abstraction, and trackable on a dashboard. Now now any analyst who reports NFT volumes in Ethereum can filter out wash traded volume (currently on L1, and we’re adopting it on Optimism). See Blog Post: NFT Wash Trading on Ethereum This kind of work to filter out the “fake” activity from on-chain data is hugely impactful to start to understand “real” usage, and make decisions that actually push the space forward vs optimize for vanity. Project Name Ankr Description Ankr provides free, public RPC endpoints for developers to easily access Optimism Mainnet and Optimism Goerli.  To quote one builder on Optimism Mainnet: “I switched my users to the Ankr public RPC and it worked far faster and without rate limiting - much better than https://mainnet.optimism.io”. At OP Labs we maintain and operate our own public RPC endpoints (https://mainnet.optimism.io and https://goerli.optimism.io) as a public good. Our team knows first-hand the cost, time, and effort required to keep nodes up and stable to scalably serve RPC requests. Even with the effort and capital we’ve put towards hosting our own public endpoints as a public good, I’ve heard from multiple builders that the free, publicly accessible Ankr endpoint enables more requests before rate limiting while remaining fast and stable. Unlike other RPC providers, Ankr doesn’t require an email signup or API key to start using its services, resulting in a seamless experience for developers to start developing on Optimism Goerli and Optimism Mainnet. Based on Ankr’s self-reported data, the endpoints average 1.4k requests/sec, with over 3.7 billion requests in the past 30 days. Links  Ankr Ankr Optimism Free-tier product  Contact  Ankr on Twitter   Disclaimers I work for OP Labs. I am making this nomination in my capacity as an individual and not on behalf of OP Labs.

The projects name: Apetimism Launchpad   A description of how the project has supported the development and usage of the OP Stack: NFT has become one of the fundamental mechanisms for web3 projects. Its utility can vary from being proof of ownership, being used as a membership card, or being a security asset. In most cases, the actual value of NFT is firmly bonded to its utility. Hence “the core business” of an NFT project is what matters. With more business-driven NFT projects, more sustainable growth could be expected in the space, which would benefit everyone in the ecosystem in both the short term and in the long run.  Speak of which, we need to reduce the barrier of those project founders who do real business to start an NFT project.  Anyway, it is worth noting that even if it looks easy to launch an NFT project, in reality, it is quite geeky and requires strong technical knowledge to start a quality one. A secured smart contract is required to ensure the smart contract has no security flaws. At the same time, a quality minting system is also necessary to give the user a flawless minting experience. Apetimism Launchpad is created to fulfill this gap and comes with the following features:   A secured and full-featured smart contract that can be deployed directly from the project founder’s wallet. The project founder would own and get full control of the smart contract deployed.  Highly dynamic minting system where the project founder can control in many degrees, for example, mint round, mint limit, ming role, mint price, etc.  Bot prevention minting system to prevent the bot from sweeping the NFT.  Highly-scalable minting system that can handle any amount of traffic to ensure the mint site would not go down under any stress.  With Apetimism Launchpad, a project founder would save weeks or months of work and reduce it to a matter of minutes, which would not only give a massive benefit to the project founder but also to the whole ecosystem since the friction to launch a quality NFT project has never been lower. Apetimism Launchpad will be integrated as a launchpad for Zonic, the upcoming NFT marketplace for L2, which will deliver close-loop experiences for creators to deliver both 1st sale and 2nd sale systems.   Links  Apetimism Launchpad  Twitter: @Apetimism   Discord: Apetimism     Contact info for the project or project lead: @nuuneoi (https://twitter.com/nuuneoi)

The projects name: Commons Stack A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Commons Stack is on a mission to enable ground-up, community driven initiatives that support public or common goods. To achieve this, years of research have gone into developing Commons design patterns which include cultural frameworks, a suite of tools and a radically inclusive methodology (Collaborative Economics) for launching a Commons DAO. We see the work of Elinor Ostrom as our North Star and set out to weave her principles of governing commons into the cultural fabric of a Commons DAO by defining practices for clear boundaries, conflict resolution, mutual monitoring, participatory decision-making, etc. We co-developed, and open-sourced, novel tools like the Augmented Bonding Curve, Conviction Voting and Praise reputation and reward system. We have only just begun. Our research continues. Lessons learned from the first field test of our design patterns, the Token Engineering Commons (TEC), are being rolled into new deployment protocols and our tools continues to evolve. A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Github Twitter (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: Twitter | @commonsstack

The projects name: Optimism Prices Contracts A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: Optimism Prices is a set of Optimism-unique smart contracts that can price any ERC20 asset that exists in a liquidity pool on Optimism, intended to replace the usage of centralized APIs for pricing data with a more reliable and trustless service. The contracts support pricing that requires complex routes with many hops, supports non-standard ERC20 implementations and non-standard AMM curves, and is even optimized to allow for large calls that can best take advantage of the public Optimism RPC without using unnecessary computation. Optimism Prices Contracts are used by Velodrome to accurately price 120+ ERC20 tokens with 100% coverage to display dollar-denominated values on the Velodrome UI and maintain accurate APR data. The Optimism Prices Contracts can entirely replace centralized pricing APIs for the majority of dapps on Optimism, and were designed with the goal of strengthening Optimism’s developer community by building tools that are simultaneously more efficient, and more trustless/verifiable. Future plans for the project include getting the Optimism Prices contracts indexed by Dune, to definitively solve some of the asset-pricing issues the community has been facing lately with not having full coverage for token prices on their dashboards. Other plans include adding support for TWAP prices for any arbitrary ERC20 asset to make the Optimism Prices Contracts viable for use cases that are more sensitive to short term price manipulation. The project’s name: NFT Watcher   A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack: The app watches NFT transfers and automatically cut the service in case of a transfer. Today, we’re seeing a growing usage of ‘access NFTs’ on Optimism (ticketing, VOD services, metaverse, …). Services usually only verify the ownership of the NFT once, in this case a user actually can use the NFT to access the service and then transfer his NFT to someone else. In other words, two persons can use the same service at the same time (which is a form of Sybil attack…). NFT Watcher solves this problem.   A link to the project’s GitHub or Twitter: Github repo | Live demo   (optional) contact info for the project or project lead: Olivier

The Project name: Quark ID Description: CONCEPTUAL APPROACH TO THE PROBLEM In the analog world we physically carry different credentials or attestations in a wallet or purse, to prove each of the aspects that are part of our identity (driver’s license, our ID card, club card, etc.). In addition, in the physical world we rely on a public or private agency to issue these verifiable documents and credentials. Just as we have many physical credentials that prove aspects of our identity, in the digital world there are many applications where we also store IDs that prove aspects of our identity: we have an app for health services, another for paying for public transportation, another for identification documents, etc. The problem is that people (holders) do not have the possibility to select which data to share, to verify an aspect of their identity or their relationship with a good or service; instead, they must present the document with all the information it contains, thus providing more data than necessary when requested. WHAT DOES QUARK ID PROPOSE TO CHANGE? All the applications we use in the digital world have their databases centralized in their datacenters and they are the ones who monopolize their users’ information. Every time we tell our browser to store our credentials for accessing any online service, we are entrusting our data to the manufacturer of that browser (Microsoft, Google, etc.). The goal of Quark ID is that everything related to our identity is under our absolute control. That is to say, that any attribute referring to our identity is defined and guarded by us and we have the power to decide with whom we share it, for what purpose and for how long. WHAT IS QUARK ID? It is a self-sovereign digital identity and security framework co-created with the community of entrepreneurs, developers and experts in Latin America, and promoted by the Government of the City of Buenos Aires, which aims to give people back control over their credentials, with a security anchor through blockchain. Quark ID enables new ways of using your personal information and redefines access to services provided by all types of institutions and organizations, whether public or private. The protocol is decentralized, public, non-permissioned, open and extensible. In addition, it is interoperable and multichain, so that each ecosystem that wants to use this technology can choose the one they prefer. This is where we frame Quark ID as a cross digital identity and security framework and that it can use any blockchain, from a Layer 1 to a Layer 2. We believe the important thing is that this works as a public infrastructure, so that anyone can build value, and to transform and simplify the way the state and society relate, while empowering people by giving them back control over their identity. WHAT IS THE PURPOSE OF QUARK ID? Quark ID seeks to put the person at the center, that is, that citizens regain control over their data and become owners of their identity. People will have their credentials (which are issued by public and private organizations) on a single off-chain platform. All this information flow is protected by a peer-to-peer interaction privacy design. That means that no intermediary can track the interactions between stakeholders. In addition, Quark ID is “all in one”, meaning that all verifiable credentials and attestations are stored in a single mobile application. No one but the users have access to the credential information and it is up to them to decide what data to send to each person or organization. QUARK ID’S MISSION Being an interoperable, open, permissive digital security framework, it is intended that any jurisdiction can adopt it. It seeks to give rise to a new paradigm in which new transactions are secure and agile. This is based on the principle that people are the ones who control their identity, and they are the ones who decide where their information is stored. BASIC PRINCIPLES OF QUARK ID  Open standards SSI protocol Multichain Interoperable Off-chain private data Autonomous governance A growing public/private ecosystem Government user vs. government user  QUARK ID: AN ECOSYSTEM An ecosystem is being generated. Many companies and municipalities started to get interested. We are working with:  Extrimian Starkware IOVlabs Beon OSCity XCapit Buenos Aires City Government   QUARK ID - SSDI-5_page-00012000×1125 183 KB  Github:  GitHub - Quark-id/WhitePaper: QuarkID Protocolo Whitpaper Website: quarkid.org

The projects name: Ante - https://www.ante.finance/  A description of how the project has supported development and usage of the OP Stack:  Ante was deployed on Optimism on 2022/11/25, and is providing a platform for users and protocols to write tests that show faith in underlying smart contracts on chain. As a dev tool (also listed on Pentacle - https://pentacle.xyz/projects/ante-finance), Ante is a way to measure decentralized community trust in on chain guarantees in real time. The ante tests themselves are on chain incentivized tests that builders on Optimism can check with their own smart contracts to see if guarantees are still true, providing greater user safety in the entire ecosystem. Project Name: Transport ICM Monitoring tools for road incident management and reducing traffic congestion powered by IPFS. Crowdsourcing information sharing for better and safer roads. How it works:  Camera Management: Add/edit/delete cameras for snapshots of road incidents. Object Detection using OSS computer vision. Video analytics configuration using IPFS. Live streaming with Object Detection, Video Analytics using IPFS. Alarm storage using Ethereum. Save/delete alarm metadata and image to/from IPFS. Store the hash returned from IPFS to Ethereum test network. Provide links to alarms and blockchain transaction details. Alarm Viewer: Add alarms with a single touch. Open the Alarm Settings menu from the home page. Add an alarm, delete an existing alarm.  Enablement using OP Eco-system: Optimism NFT marketplace for vehicle spare parts and also for early-stage detection and prevention of incidents. Improving Data Transparency in Incident Management Using Ethereum Blockchain, IPFS and Optimism NFT marketplace. We are extending and adapting our platform for connected vehicles in Europe for sustainability and efficiency. We are currently working on a dataset of 15000 trips, 45+ trucks and 175+ drivers and enabling them to achieve better fleet management. We wish to use Optimism for scaling the solution for the current dataset.
